1.brief: properly, a pithy maxim, usually of metaphorical nature; hence, a simile (as an adage, poem, discourse)
a son (as a builder of the family name), in the widest sense (of literal and figurative relationship, including grandson, subject, nation, quality or condition, etc., (like father or brother), etc.)
David, the youngest son of Jesse
Jisrael, a symbolical name of Jacob; also (typically) of his posterity

2.brief: to know (properly, to ascertain by seeing); used in a great variety of senses, figuratively, literally, euphemistically and inferentially (including observation, care, recognition; and causatively, instruction, designation, punishment, etc.)
properly, chastisement; figuratively, reproof, warning or instruction; also restraint
to separate mentally (or distinguish), i.e.(generally) understand

3.brief: to take (in the widest variety of applications)
properly, chastisement; figuratively, reproof, warning or instruction; also restraint
to be (causatively, make or act) circumspect and hence, intelligent
the right (natural, moral or legal); also (abstractly) equity or (figuratively) prosperity

properly, a verdict (favorable or unfavorable) pronounced judicially, especially a sentence or formal decree (human or (participant's) divine law, individual or collective), including the act, the place, the suit, the crime, and the penalty; abstractly, justice, including a participant's right or privilege (statutory or customary), or even a style
evenness, i.e. (figuratively) prosperity or concord; also straightness, i.e. (figuratively) rectitude (only in plural with singular sense; often adverbially)

4.brief: to give, used with greatest latitude of application (put, make, etc.)
trickery; or (in a good sense) discretion
(concretely) a boy (as active), from the age of infancy to adolescence; by implication, a servant; also (by interch. of sex), a girl (of similar latitude in age)
a plan, usually evil (machination), sometimes good (sagacity)

5.brief: to hear intelligently (often with implication of attention, obedience, etc.; causatively, to tell, etc.)
to add or augment (often adverbial, to continue to do a thing)
properly, something received, i.e. (mentally) instruction (whether on the part of the teacher or hearer); also (in an active and sinister sense) inveiglement
to separate mentally (or distinguish), i.e.(generally) understand
(only in plural) properly, steerage (as a management of ropes), i.e. (figuratively) guidance or (by implication) a plan
to erect, i.e. create; by extension, to procure, especially by purchase (causatively, sell); by implication to own

6.brief: to separate mentally (or distinguish), i.e.(generally) understand
properly, a pithy maxim, usually of metaphorical nature; hence, a simile (as an adage, poem, discourse)
a word; by implication, a matter (as spoken of) or thing; adverbially, a cause
a puzzle, hence, a trick, conundrum, sententious maxim

7.brief: fear (also used as infinitive); morally, reverence
Jehovah, Jewish national name of God
the first, in place, time, order or rank (specifically, a firstfruit)
properly, chastisement; figuratively, reproof, warning or instruction; also restraint

8.brief: to hear intelligently (often with implication of attention, obedience, etc.; causatively, to tell, etc.)
a son (as a builder of the family name), in the widest sense (of literal and figurative relationship, including grandson, subject, nation, quality or condition, etc., (like father or brother), etc.)
properly, chastisement; figuratively, reproof, warning or instruction; also restraint
father, in a literal and immediate, or figurative and remote application
not (the qualified negation, used as a deprecative); once (Job 24:25) as a noun, nothing
properly, to pound, i.e. smite; by implication (as if beating out, and thus expanding) to disperse; also, to thrust off, down, out or upon (inclusively, reject, let alone, permit, remit, etc.)
a precept or statute, especially the Decalogue or Pentateuch
a mother (as the bond of the family); in a wide sense (both literally and figuratively (like father))

9.brief: (by implication) very widely used as a relative conjunction or adverb (as below); often largely modified by other particles annexed
graciousness, i.e. subjective (kindness, favor) or objective (beauty)
the head (as most easily shaken), whether literal or figurative (in many applications, of place, time, rank, itc.)

10.brief: a son (as a builder of the family name), in the widest sense (of literal and figurative relationship, including grandson, subject, nation, quality or condition, etc., (like father or brother), etc.)
used very widely as demonstrative, lo!; interrogative, whether?; or conditional, if, although; also Oh that!, when; hence, as a negative, not
to open, i.e. be (causatively, make) roomy; usually figuratively (in a mental or moral sense) to be (causatively, make) simple or (in a sinister way) delude
a criminal, or one accounted guilty
not (the qualified negation, used as a deprecative); once (Job 24:25) as a noun, nothing
to breathe after, i.e. (figuratively) to be acquiescent

11.brief: used very widely as demonstrative, lo!; interrogative, whether?; or conditional, if, although; also Oh that!, when; hence, as a negative, not
to walk (literally or figuratively); causatively, to carry (in various senses)
properly, nearness (used only as a preposition or an adverb), near; hence, generally, with, by, at, among, etc.
blood (as that which when shed causes death) of man or an animal; by analogy, the juice of the grape; figuratively (especially in the plural) bloodshed (i.e. drops of blood)
to hide (by covering over); by implication, to hoard or reserve; figuratively to deny; specifically (favorably) to protect, (unfavorably) to lurk
gratis, i.e. devoid of cost, reason or advantage

12.brief: to make away with (specifically by swallowing); generally, to destroy
Hades or the world of the dead (as if a subterranean retreat), including its accessories and inmates
alive; hence, raw (flesh); fresh (plant, water, year), strong; also (as noun, especially in the feminine singular and masculine plural) life (or living thing), whether literally or figuratively
entire (literally, figuratively or morally); also (as noun) integrity, truth

to descend (literally, to go downwards; or conventionally to a lower region, as the shore, a boundary, the enemy, etc.; or figuratively, to fall); causatively, to bring down (in all the above applications)
a pit hole (especially one used as a cistern or a prison)

13.brief: properly, the whole; hence, all, any or every (in the singular only, but often in a plural sense)
properly, to come forth to, i.e. appear or exist; transitively, to attain, i.e. find or acquire; figuratively, to occur, meet or be present
to fill or (intransitively) be full of, in a wide application (literally and figuratively)
a house (in the greatest variation of applications, especially family, etc.)

14.brief: properly, a pebble, i.e. a lot (small stones being used for that purpose); figuratively, a portion or destiny (as if determined by lot)
to fall, in a great variety of applications (intransitive or causative, literal or figurative)
a bisection, i.e. (by implication) the centre
a cup; also a bag formoney or weights
properly, united, i.e. one; or (as an ordinal) first
to exist, i.e. be or become, come to pass (always emphatic, and not a mere copula or auxiliary)
properly, the whole; hence, all, any or every (in the singular only, but often in a plural sense)

15.brief: a son (as a builder of the family name), in the widest sense (of literal and figurative relationship, including grandson, subject, nation, quality or condition, etc., (like father or brother), etc.)
not (the qualified negation, used as a deprecative); once (Job 24:25) as a noun, nothing
to walk (literally or figuratively); causatively, to carry (in various senses)
a road (as trodden); figuratively, a course of life or mode of action, often adverb
properly, nearness (used only as a preposition or an adverb), near; hence, generally, with, by, at, among, etc.
to debar (negatively or positively) from benefit or injury
a foot (as used in walking); by implication, a step; by euphemistically the pudenda

16.brief: (by implication) very widely used as a relative conjunction or adverb (as below); often largely modified by other particles annexed
a foot (as used in walking); by implication, a step; by euphemistically the pudenda
bad or (as noun) evil (natural or moral)
to run (for whatever reason, especially to rush)
properly, to be liquid or flow easily, i.e. (by implication); to hurry (in a good or a bad sense); often used (with another verb) adverbially, promptly
to spill forth (blood, a libation, liquid metal; or even a solid, i.e. to mound up); also (figuratively) to expend (life, soul, complaint, money, etc.); intensively, to sprawl out
blood (as that which when shed causes death) of man or an animal; by analogy, the juice of the grape; figuratively (especially in the plural) bloodshed (i.e. drops of blood)

17.brief: (by implication) very widely used as a relative conjunction or adverb (as below); often largely modified by other particles annexed
gratis, i.e. devoid of cost, reason or advantage
to toss about; by implication, to diffuse, winnow
an eye (literally or figuratively); by analogy, a fountain (as the eye of the landscape)
properly, the whole; hence, all, any or every (in the singular only, but often in a plural sense)
a master; hence, a husband, or (figuratively) owner (often used with another noun in modifications of this latter sense)
an edge or extremity; specifically (of a bird or army) a wing, (of a garment or bedclothing) a flap, (of the earth) a quarter, (of a building) a pinnacle

18.brief: blood (as that which when shed causes death) of man or an animal; by analogy, the juice of the grape; figuratively (especially in the plural) bloodshed (i.e. drops of blood)
to hide (by covering over); by implication, to hoard or reserve; figuratively to deny; specifically (favorably) to protect, (unfavorably) to lurk
properly, a breathing creature, i.e. animal of (abstractly) vitality; used very widely in a literal, accommodated or figurative sense (bodily or mental)

19.brief: properly, set upright; hence (figuratively as adjective) just; but usually (as adverb or conjunction) rightly or so (in various applications to manner, time and relation; often with other particles)
a well-trodden road (literally or figuratively); also a caravan
properly, the whole; hence, all, any or every (in the singular only, but often in a plural sense)
properly, self (but generally used to point out more definitely the object of a verb or preposition, even or namely)
properly, a breathing creature, i.e. animal of (abstractly) vitality; used very widely in a literal, accommodated or figurative sense (bodily or mental)
a master; hence, a husband, or (figuratively) owner (often used with another noun in modifications of this latter sense)
to take (in the widest variety of applications)

20.brief: properly, separate by awall, i.e. outside, outdoors
properly, to creak (or emit a stridulous sound), i.e. to shout (usually for joy)
a width, i.e. (concretely) avenue or area
to give, used with greatest latitude of application (put, make, etc.)

21.brief: the head (as most easily shaken), whether literal or figurative (in many applications, of place, time, rank, itc.)
to make a loud sound (like English 'hum'); by implication, to be in great commotion or tumult, to rage, war, moan, clamor
to call out to (i.e. properly, address by name, but used in a wide variety of applications)
an opening (literally), i.e. door (gate) or entrance way
an opening, i.e. door or gate
a city (a place guarded by waking or a watch) in the widest sense (even of a mere encampment or post)

22.brief: as far (or long, or much) as, whether of space (even unto) or time (during, while, until) or degree (equally with)
properly, extent (of time); but used only adverbially (especially with other particle prefixes), when (either relative or interrogative)
to have affection for (sexually or otherwise)
properly, to make mouths at, i.e. to scoff; hence (from the effort to pronounce a foreign language) to interpret, or (generally) intercede
properly, fat, i.e. (figuratively) stupid or silly

23.brief: to turn back (hence, away) transitively or intransitively, literally or figuratively (not necessarily with the idea of return to the starting point); generally to retreat; often adverbial, again
chastisement; figuratively (by words) correction, refutation, proof (even in defence)
to gush forth; figuratively, to utter (good or bad words); specifically, to emit (a foul odor)

wind; by resemblance breath, i.e. a sensible (or even violent) exhalation; figuratively, life, anger, unsubstantiality; by extension, a region of the sky; by resemblance spirit, but only of a rational being (including its expression and functions)

to know (properly, to ascertain by seeing); used in a great variety of senses, figuratively, literally, euphemistically and inferentially (including observation, care, recognition; and causatively, instruction, designation, punishment, etc.)
a word; by implication, a matter (as spoken of) or thing; adverbially, a cause
properly, self (but generally used to point out more definitely the object of a verb or preposition, even or namely)

24.brief: properly, heed; by implication, purpose (sake or account); used adverbially to indicate the reason or cause
to call out to (i.e. properly, address by name, but used in a wide variety of applications)
to stretch or spread out; by implication, to bend away (including moral deflection); used in a great variety of application
a hand (the open one (indicating power, means, direction, etc.),
a non-entity; generally used as a negative particle
to prick up the ears, i.e. hearken

25.brief: to loosen; by implication, to expose, dismiss; figuratively, absolve, begin
properly, the whole; hence, all, any or every (in the singular only, but often in a plural sense)
advice; by implication, plan; also prudence
chastisement; figuratively (by words) correction, refutation, proof (even in defence)
not (the simple or abs. negation); by implication, no; often used with other particles
to breathe after, i.e. (figuratively) to be acquiescent

26.brief: properly, assemblage; used only adverbially also, even, yea, though; often repeated as correl. both...and
to laugh (in pleasure or detraction); by implication, to play
to deride; by implication (as if imitating a foreigner) to speak unintelligibly
to go or come (in a wide variety of applications)
a (sudden) alarm (properly, the object feared, by implication, the feeling)

27.brief: to go or come (in a wide variety of applications)
a (sudden) alarm (properly, the object feared, by implication, the feeling)
to go or come (in a wide variety of applications)
above, over, upon, or against (yet always in this last relation with a downward aspect) in a great variety of applications
tightness (i.e. figuratively, trouble); transitively, a female rival:

28.brief: at that time or place; also as a conjunction, therefore
to call out to (i.e. properly, address by name, but used in a wide variety of applications)
not (the simple or abs. negation); by implication, no; often used with other particles
properly, to eye or (generally) to heed, i.e. pay attention; by implication, to respond; by extension to begin to speak; specifically to sing, shout, testify, announce
properly, to dawn, i.e. (figuratively) be (up) early at any task (with the implication of earnestness); by extension, to search for (with painstaking)
not (the simple or abs. negation); by implication, no; often used with other particles
properly, to come forth to, i.e. appear or exist; transitively, to attain, i.e. find or acquire; figuratively, to occur, meet or be present

29.brief: the bottom (as depressed); only adverbially, below (often with prepositional prefix underneath), in lieu of, etc.
(by implication) very widely used as a relative conjunction or adverb (as below); often largely modified by other particles annexed
fear (also used as infinitive); morally, reverence
Jehovah, Jewish national name of God
not (the simple or abs. negation); by implication, no; often used with other particles
properly, to try, i.e. (by implication) select

30.brief: not (the simple or abs. negation); by implication, no; often used with other particles
to breathe after, i.e. (figuratively) to be acquiescent
advice; by implication, plan; also prudence
properly, the whole; hence, all, any or every (in the singular only, but often in a plural sense)
chastisement; figuratively (by words) correction, refutation, proof (even in defence)

31.brief: a road (as trodden); figuratively, a course of life or mode of action, often adverb
to sate, i.e. fill to satisfaction (literally or figuratively)

32.brief: (by implication) very widely used as a relative conjunction or adverb (as below); often largely modified by other particles annexed
properly, fat, i.e. (figuratively) stupid or silly
properly, to wander away, i.e. lose oneself; by implication to perish (causative, destroy)

33.brief: to hear intelligently (often with implication of attention, obedience, etc.; causatively, to tell, etc.)
to reside or permanently stay (literally or figuratively)
properly, a place of refuge; abstract, safety, both the fact (security) and the feeling (trust); often (adverb with or without preposition) safely
a (sudden) alarm (properly, the object feared, by implication, the feeling)
bad or (as noun) evil (natural or moral)
